title: Amoebic Liver Abscess
chief_complaint: Right upper quadrant pain and fever for 10 days
presentation: A 38-year-old truck driver presents with right upper quadrant pain, high-grade fever with chills, and right shoulder tip pain for 10 days. He consumes alcohol (country liquor) regularly and has poor dietary hygiene. He was initially treated for pneumonia with no improvement.
history: Right upper quadrant pain for 10 days, dull aching, radiating to right shoulder. High-grade fever with rigors and chills. Anorexia, nausea. Dry cough (reactive from diaphragmatic irritation). No jaundice. No diarrhea currently (but had bloody diarrhea 3 months ago, self-treated). Truck driver, eats at roadside dhabas. Drinks country liquor regularly. Treated with ceftriaxone for 5 days (suspected pneumonia) - no improvement.
physical_exam: Febrile, appears toxic. Tender hepatomegaly (liver 6 cm below costal margin, smooth, tender). Intercostal tenderness right lower chest. Right basal crepitations (reactive effusion). No jaundice. No splenomegaly. No ascites. Positive punch sign (tenderness on fist percussion over liver).
investigations: USG abdomen: Large solitary abscess right lobe of liver (10 x 8 cm, hypoechoic with internal echoes, 'anchovy sauce' appearance). No biliary dilatation. Amoebic serology (IgG ELISA): Strongly positive. CBC: WBC 18,000 (neutrophilia), Hb 11, Platelets normal. LFT: ALP 350 (elevated), AST 65, ALT 55, Bilirubin 1.5. CXR: Right pleural effusion (reactive), elevated right hemidiaphragm. Stool: No cysts/trophozoites (negative in >50% of liver abscess). Blood culture: Negative (helps rule out pyogenic).
learning_points: Amoebic vs Pyogenic liver abscess: Amoebic = young male, solitary, right lobe, positive serology. Pyogenic = elderly, multiple, may have biliary disease, blood culture positive
Anchovy sauce/chocolate sauce pus is classic for amoebic abscess
Stool examination is negative in >50% of amoebic liver abscess (intestinal phase may have resolved)
Treatment: Metronidazole 750mg TID for 7-10 days + luminal agent (diloxanide furoate/paromomycin)
Aspiration indications: >5 cm, left lobe (risk of rupture into pericardium), no response to drugs in 72 hours
Complication: Rupture into peritoneum, pleura, or pericardium (left lobe abscess)
india_context: India has the highest global burden of amoebiasis. Poor sanitation, contaminated water, and food-handling practices drive transmission. Truck drivers are particularly vulnerable due to eating at unhygienic roadside eateries. Metronidazole is widely available and affordable. Image-guided aspiration is available at district hospitals.

title: Acute Pancreatitis - Alcohol-Related with Pseudocyst
chief_complaint: Severe epigastric pain radiating to back for 2 days
presentation: A 42-year-old fisherman from Kerala presents with severe boring epigastric pain radiating to the back for 2 days, worsened by eating and partially relieved by leaning forward. He has a history of heavy alcohol consumption (toddy and arrack). He has had 3 prior episodes of acute pancreatitis. He presents with vomiting, abdominal distension, and fever.
history: Severe epigastric pain for 2 days, boring quality, radiating straight to the back. Worse on eating, partially relieved by leaning forward (pancreatic position). Persistent vomiting. Abdominal distension. Stopped passing flatus (ileus). Heavy alcohol intake: toddy and arrack daily for 20 years, binge 3 days ago. 3 previous episodes of pancreatitis (twice hospitalized). No gallstone history. No recent medications (no steroids, azathioprine, valproate).
physical_exam: Dehydrated, tachycardic, hypotensive. Epigastric tenderness and guarding. Distended abdomen with absent bowel sounds (paralytic ileus). Cullen sign: Periumbilical ecchymosis. Grey-Turner sign: Flank ecchymosis (hemorrhagic pancreatitis). No jaundice. Reduced breath sounds bilateral bases (pleural effusions). Shifting dullness positive (ascites).
investigations: Serum amylase: 1800 U/L (>3x upper limit). Serum lipase: 2500 U/L. CT abdomen (contrast, after 72 hours): Bulky pancreas with peripancreatic fat stranding, peripancreatic fluid collections, 40% necrosis (necrotizing pancreatitis), left pleural effusion, ascites. 6 cm pseudocyst in lesser sac (from previous episode). CTSI (CT Severity Index): 8/10 (severe). CBC: WBC 19,000, Hb 14 (hemoconcentration). CRP: 280. Calcium: 6.8 mg/dL (hypocalcemia - Cullen sign). LFT: Mildly deranged. Renal: Creatinine 2.2 (AKI). BUN: 45. Triglycerides: Normal. APACHE II: 12 (severe).
diagnosis: Severe acute alcohol-related necrotizing pancreatitis with organ failure, pre-existing pseudocyst
learning_points: Revised Atlanta Classification: Mild (no organ failure), Moderately severe (transient organ failure <48h), Severe (persistent organ failure >48h)
CTSI/Balthazar score predicts severity and necrosis extent
Cullen and Grey-Turner signs indicate hemorrhagic pancreatitis (retroperitoneal hemorrhage)
Management: Aggressive fluid resuscitation (Ringer lactate), pain control, NPO → early enteral nutrition (nasojejunal)
Infected necrosis: Suspect if fever >7-10 days. Confirm with FNA + culture. Treat with step-up approach (PCD → endoscopic/minimally invasive necrosectomy → open surgery)
Pseudocyst: Encapsulated fluid collection >4 weeks. Drain if symptomatic or >6 cm
india_context: Alcohol is the commonest cause of acute pancreatitis in South India (toddy/arrack consumption). Gallstones are the commonest cause in North India. Kerala has among the highest per-capita alcohol consumption in India. Step-up approach for infected necrosis has been adopted by most Indian GI centers (video-assisted retroperitoneal debridement - VARD).

title: Hepatitis B - Chronic with Decompensated Cirrhosis
chief_complaint: Abdominal distension, jaundice, and confusion for 1 week
presentation: A 50-year-old government employee from Mizoram presents with progressive abdominal distension for 3 months, deepening jaundice for 2 weeks, and confusion with altered sleep-wake cycle for 5 days. He was diagnosed with Hepatitis B 10 years ago but never followed up. Mizoram has the highest HBV prevalence in India (>5%).
history: Progressive abdominal distension for 3 months (ascites). Bilateral leg swelling for 2 months. Jaundice deepening for 2 weeks. Confusion, drowsiness, inverted sleep-wake cycle for 5 days. One episode of hematemesis (large volume) 2 days ago. Known HBsAg positive for 10 years, never treated, no follow-up. No alcohol. Lives in Aizawl, Mizoram (high HBV endemicity - vertical transmission common). Family: Mother died of 'liver cancer' at 55.
physical_exam: Deeply icteric, confused (Grade II hepatic encephalopathy). Asterixis present. Fetor hepaticus. Spider naevi on upper chest. Palmar erythema. Gynecomastia. Testicular atrophy. Tense ascites. Splenomegaly (portal hypertension). Caput medusae. Bilateral pedal edema. Shrunken liver (not palpable). Dilated veins on abdominal wall.
investigations: HBsAg: Positive. HBeAg: Negative. Anti-HBe: Positive. HBV DNA: 25,000 IU/mL (active replication). Anti-HCV: Negative. Anti-HDV: Negative. AFP: 450 ng/mL (suspicious for HCC). LFT: Bilirubin 12, AST 120, ALT 85, Albumin 1.8, INR 2.8. CBC: Hb 8.5, WBC 3,200, Platelets 55,000 (pancytopenia - hypersplenism). Renal: Creatinine 1.8, Na+ 125 (dilutional). Ascitic fluid: SAAG 2.1 (portal hypertension), protein 1.5, WBC 350 (PMN 280 - SBP). USG: Shrunken liver, coarse echotexture, splenomegaly, ascites, portal vein 14mm. 3 cm lesion in right lobe (? HCC). Triple-phase CT: Arterial enhancing lesion 3 cm in segment VII with washout (LIRADS-5, definite HCC). Child-Pugh Score: C (12 points). MELD: 28.
diagnosis: Chronic Hepatitis B with decompensated cirrhosis (Child-Pugh C), spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and hepatic encephalopathy
learning_points: HBV is the commonest cause of cirrhosis and HCC in Northeast India and Asia
Screen all HBV cirrhotics for HCC: USG + AFP every 6 months
SBP diagnosis: Ascitic fluid PMN >250 cells/mm³ - treat with IV ceftriaxone empirically
Hepatic encephalopathy: Lactulose + rifaximin, identify and treat precipitants (SBP, GI bleed)
Child-Pugh C with MELD >15: Liver transplant evaluation
Antiviral: Tenofovir or Entecavir indefinitely in decompensated cirrhosis
india_context: India has ~40 million HBV carriers (3-4% prevalence). Northeast states (Mizoram, Arunachal, Nagaland) have >5% prevalence due to vertical transmission and cultural practices. Universal HBV vaccination in UIP since 2007 (birth dose). INASL recommends Tenofovir as first-line for HBV. Liver transplantation available at ~50 centers in India; living donor transplant is commonest (80%).

title: Celiac Disease Presenting with Iron Deficiency Anemia
source: Indian Journal of Gastroenterology - Celiac Disease
chief_complaint: Chronic diarrhea, fatigue, and severe anemia
presentation: A 22-year-old Punjabi college student presents with chronic loose stools for 2 years, progressive fatigue, and severe pallor. She has been treated with multiple courses of iron supplements without improvement. She has had recurrent aphthous ulcers and delayed menarche (first period at 16). She consumes a wheat-heavy Punjabi diet (roti with every meal).
history: Chronic loose stools for 2 years - 3-4 times/day, bulky, pale, foul-smelling, float on water (steatorrhea). Abdominal bloating after meals (especially roti/chapati). Progressive fatigue and weakness. Severe pallor. Multiple iron supplement courses - no response (refractory iron deficiency anemia). Recurrent aphthous ulcers. Delayed menarche (16 years). Short stature for family. Weight loss 5 kg. Diet: Heavy wheat consumption (roti with every meal - Punjabi diet). Younger brother also has chronic diarrhea.
physical_exam: Pale, thin. BMI 17. Angular cheilitis. Glossitis (smooth, beefy-red tongue). Multiple aphthous ulcers. Koilonychia. Dry, rough skin (dermatitis herpetiformis - itchy papulovesicular rash on elbows and knees). Mild abdominal distension, no tenderness. No hepatosplenomegaly. Short stature (150 cm, family average 162 cm).
investigations: Anti-tTG IgA: >200 U/mL (strongly positive, normal <20). Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA): Positive. Total serum IgA: Normal (rules out IgA deficiency causing false-negative). HLA-DQ2: Positive. Upper GI endoscopy: Scalloping of duodenal folds, mosaic pattern, loss of villi. Duodenal biopsy: Marsh 3c (total villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, increased intraepithelial lymphocytes). CBC: Hb 6.5, MCV 68 (microcytic), Ferritin 3 (depleted). Iron studies: Low serum iron, high TIBC. Calcium: 7.8 (low). Vitamin D: 8 ng/mL (deficient). B12: Low-normal. Folate: Low. DEXA: Osteopenia. TSH: Normal. LFT: Mildly elevated transaminases.
diagnosis: Celiac disease with iron deficiency anemia (refractory to oral iron), steatorrhea, and metabolic bone disease
learning_points: Celiac disease is increasingly recognized in North India (wheat belt) - prevalence ~1%
Refractory iron deficiency anemia not responding to oral iron: Think celiac disease
Anti-tTG IgA is the best screening test; biopsy remains gold standard
Marsh classification: 0 (normal) to 3c (total villous atrophy)
Treatment: Strict lifelong gluten-free diet (avoid wheat, barley, rye)
Celiac diet in Punjab is challenging: Rice, corn (makki), millet (bajra) as wheat substitutes
india_context: Celiac disease prevalence in North India (Punjab, Haryana, Delhi, Rajasthan) is ~1% - comparable to Western countries. The 'wheat belt' of India has the highest prevalence. Previously thought rare in India, now increasingly diagnosed. ICMR recommends screening in: refractory IDA, type 1 DM, autoimmune thyroid disease, Down syndrome, first-degree relatives. Gluten-free products are increasingly available but expensive.

title: Acute Upper GI Bleed - Variceal
presentation: A 48-year-old farmer presents with sudden onset massive hematemesis (bright red blood, estimated 500 mL) and melena for 6 hours. He has a known history of alcohol-related cirrhosis but has not been compliant with follow-up. He is hemodynamically unstable with altered sensorium.
history: Sudden massive hematemesis - 3 episodes of bright red blood (estimated 500 mL total). Melena (black tarry stools) for 6 hours. Known alcohol-related cirrhosis diagnosed 3 years ago (biopsy-proven). Was advised beta-blocker prophylaxis but not compliant. Heavy alcohol intake (arrack, 15 years). No recent NSAID or aspirin use. Previous endoscopy: Grade III esophageal varices (3 years ago, no banding done). Confused on arrival.
physical_exam: Pale, diaphoretic, altered sensorium (GCS 12). Icteric. Spider naevi. Palmar erythema. Ascites. Splenomegaly. Caput medusae. Bilateral pedal edema. PR: Melena on glove. No fresh blood in rectum.
investigations: CBC: Hb 5.5 (acute blood loss + chronic disease), WBC 8,000, Platelets 68,000. INR: 2.2. LFT: Bilirubin 5.5, Albumin 2.0, AST 85, ALT 55. Renal: Creatinine 1.8. Blood group: O+ve. Crossmatch sent for 4 units. Lactate: 5.5 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy (after resuscitation): Grade IV esophageal varices with active spurting (Baveno classification), red wale marks, cherry red spots. Successful band ligation of 3 varices. USG: Cirrhotic liver, portal vein 15 mm (portal hypertension), ascites, splenomegaly.
diagnosis: Acute variceal upper GI hemorrhage secondary to portal hypertension from alcohol-related cirrhosis
learning_points: Acute variceal bleed management: Airway + Resuscitation + IV terlipressin/octreotide + IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone) + URGENT endoscopy (<12 hours)
Endoscopic band ligation (EBL) is first-line for esophageal varices; cyanoacrylate glue for gastric varices
Restrictive transfusion: Target Hb 7-8 g/dL (over-transfusion increases portal pressure)
Antibiotics (ceftriaxone 1g IV/day x 7 days) reduce rebleeding and mortality
TIPS (transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt) for refractory bleeding
Secondary prophylaxis: Beta-blocker (carvedilol) + repeat EBL sessions until variceal eradication
india_context: Alcohol-related cirrhosis is the commonest cause of portal hypertension in South and West India. Hepatitis B/C-related cirrhosis dominates in Northeast and North India. INASL recommends screening endoscopy for all cirrhotic patients. EBL is available at most medical college hospitals. TIPS availability is limited to select tertiary centers.

title: Intestinal Tuberculosis Mimicking Crohn's Disease
chief_complaint: Chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss for 4 months
presentation: A 28-year-old schoolteacher from Kolkata presents with chronic right iliac fossa pain, alternating diarrhea and constipation, weight loss of 7 kg, and evening fevers for 4 months. Colonoscopy shows ileocecal ulceration. The critical diagnostic dilemma is: Is this intestinal TB or Crohn's disease? Starting the wrong treatment could be fatal.
history: Right iliac fossa pain for 4 months, colicky, postprandial. Alternating diarrhea and constipation. No blood in stools. Weight loss 7 kg. Evening low-grade fever. Night sweats. Anorexia. No joint pains, eye symptoms, skin lesions (no extraintestinal Crohn features). No perianal disease. No family history of IBD. Contact with TB patient (colleague). No prior TB treatment.
physical_exam: Thin, pale. Tender mass palpable in right iliac fossa (ileocecal thickening). No perianal disease (important - Crohn commonly has perianal fistulae). No oral ulcers. No erythema nodosum. No joint swelling. Mild ascites. No hepatosplenomegaly.
investigations: Colonoscopy: Circumferential ulcers in cecum and terminal ileum, nodularity, stricture at ileocecal valve. Biopsy: Granulomas with caseation (favoring TB). GeneXpert on biopsy tissue: MTB detected. AFB stain: Negative. CT abdomen: Ileocecal wall thickening (circumferential), mesenteric lymphadenopathy with necrotic centers (caseous), mild ascites. Ascitic fluid ADA: 40 U/L (elevated). CXR: Normal. Mantoux: 20 mm. CBC: Hb 9.5, ESR 60. CRP: 55. Albumin: 2.8. Fecal calprotectin: Elevated.
learning_points: TB vs Crohn's is the most important differential in Indian gastroenterology
Features favoring TB: Circumferential ulcers, caseating granulomas, necrotic lymph nodes, ascites, positive GeneXpert, response to ATT
Features favoring Crohn's: Longitudinal ulcers, non-caseating granulomas, skip lesions, perianal disease, cobblestoning, extraintestinal manifestations
GeneXpert on tissue biopsy has 50-70% sensitivity for intestinal TB
When in doubt in India: Empirical ATT trial for 8 weeks (if TB, dramatic improvement; if Crohn's, no response)
NEVER start immunosuppression (steroids/biologics for Crohn's) without ruling out TB - can cause disseminated TB
india_context: The TB vs Crohn's dilemma is unique to TB-endemic countries like India. Incidence of both is rising. Starting anti-TNF biologics (infliximab) for misdiagnosed Crohn's in a TB patient can be fatal. ICMR and ISG recommend: In diagnostic doubt, treat for TB first. All patients planned for biologics must have TB screening (GeneXpert, IGRA, CXR).
